Father is sending me to finishing school.

Join the Great American Railroad!
Three meals a day. Roof over your head.
See the open plains of America!
Opportunity awaits you, sir, out on the rails!
I know I don't come from much, but...
I will take care of your daughter and I will give her a life as grand as this one.
Sooner or later, she'll tire of your life...
of having nothing, and she'll come running back home.

âª Ev'ry night I lie in bed âª âª The brightest colors fill my head âª âª A million dreams are keepin' me awake âª âª I think of what the world could be âª âª A vision of the one I see âª âª A million dreams is all it's gonna take âª âª Oh, a million dreams âª âª For the world we're gonna make âª âª However big, however small âª âª Let me be a part of it all âª âª Share your dreams with me âª âª You may be right, you may be wrong âª âª But say that you'll bring me along âª âª To the world you see âª BOTH: âª To the world I close my eyes to see âª âª I close my eyes to see âª âª Cause ev'ry night I lie in bed âª âª The brightest colors fill my head âª âª A million dreams are keepin' me awake âª âª A million dreams, a million dreams âª BOTH: âª I think of what the world could be âª âª A vision of the one I see âª âª A million dreams is all it's gonna take âª âª A million dreams for the world âª âª We're gonna make âª âª For the world we're gonna make âª  CHALMERS: Mr. Smith?
CHALMERS: Have a look at this.
SMITH: Yes, yes, I see it.
Uh, if I may, sir, I believe I have skills and ideas that go well beyond punching numbers into an adding machine.
Well, I've read about this German fellow, Lilienthal, I believe, who's developed a glider that can take a man in the air, sir.
I mean, if you were to apply that to this business,  it would be revolutionary.
I thought the company had a dozen trading ships.
Yes, at the bottom of the South China Sea.
Well, I didn't think you were long for that job.
That's what makes our life together so exciting.
This isn't the life I promised you.
But I have everything I want.
What do you call those two girls?
Hey, you partners, look who moseyed into the corral.
Okay, I do have a present...
but not just any present. Oh, no.
The most amazing birthday present ever.
This extraordinary machine was originally created by Leonardo da Vinci, 400 years ago.
But the blueprints had been lost for centuries until just last week, on a stormy night, when a sunken pirate ship washed up on the shores of Nantucket.
They found skeletons and treasures and the blueprints were recovered by none other than J.W. Mercantile.
The blueprints crossed my desk very briefly but I managed to commit them to memory.
And if I have remembered correctly...
and it keeps them safe until they come true.
Even if you forget them, they're always there.
I wish to marry Santa Claus.
Hey, that's... that's a good wish, too.
for happiness like this forever for you and you...
Since when has happiness ever been boring?

This bank only wants to lend money to people with money.
What are you looking at, flopdoodle?
This venture you propose is risky and somewhat bizarre.
It's a good bet is what it is, sir.
People don't want to admit it...
but they're fascinated with the exotic and the macabre.
It's why we stare at it.
The bank is going to need substantial collateral.
The deed and title to my entire flotilla of trading vessels.
CHARITY: Why would a bank loan us $10,000?
But, dear, we don't have any collateral.
Sure we do. In the South China Seas.
CHARITY: In the South China Seas?
Deep in the South China Seas.  CHARITY: And what did we buy with this loan?
"Barnum's American Museum of Curiosities." What kind of museum is it?
A place where people can see things they've never seen before.
They're all the rage in Europe. Look.
Marie Antoinette with the sore throat. Napoleon.
You've already met some of the most famous folks in history.
You don't look like a magician.
I caught him nicking my watch.
I can get you somethin' real nice.
Oh, yeah. This is a tenton bull straight from the plains of Africa.
The tallest giraffe in the world.
CAROLINE: Can I climb up its leg?
Now... I know how it looks.
If you didn't, I'd be worried.
I mean, it just needs a little work, but...
The loan has to be paid back every month.
Oh, yeah, we're gonna pay it.
It is one hour of your time, sir, but it will change your life.
We have shows on the hour every hour.
Surely not for the faint of heart, but I can tell you're gonna love it.
Half price for anyone who's wearing a hat.
Welcome to the Barnum Museum, where everyone's special...
Did you sell any more tickets today?
Most everyone was rushing home, it's Friday, but...
I think you have too many dead things in your museum, Daddy.
She's right. You need something alive.
Go to sleep, both of you.
HELEN: Well, mermaids aren't real either.
The hospital record says you do.
I am putting together a show and I need a star.
You want people to laugh at me.
Well, they're laughing anyway, kid, so might as well get paid.
I see a soldier, no, a general riding across the stage with a sword and a gun, and... and...
And the most beautiful uniform ever made.
People will come from all over the world, and when they see him, they won't laugh.

I know where you can find one of them.
I'm sorry. Who's doing that singing?
WOMAN: Sir, I'll have to ask you to leave.
They don't understand, but they will.

PHINEAS: Terrific. And what do you do?
You know, people aren't gonna like it if you put us on the stage.
Terrific. I don't need to see it.
Can I just ask how heavy you are?
Do you have a number for that?
I prefer not to say, but...
Yeah, we're gonna change that name.
That's good, but I need it five times bigger!
Carriages, sides of trains, trolleys, crates, milk bottles, everywhere they look!

MAN: One for me, one for the lady.
Ah, Mr. Bennett from the Herald.
Come to take in another show, huh?
Tell me, Mr. Barnum, does it bother you that everything you're selling is fake?
It doesn't matter where they come from.
Well, hyperbole isn't the worst crime.
Men suffer more from imagining too little than too much.
The creed of a true fraud.
Mr. Bennett, when was the last time you smiled or had a good laugh?
A theater critic who can't find joy in the theater.
That word you used to describe my show?
Has a nice ring to it.
Don't you think there's enough blind trust in my life?
Well, isn't that what makes it fun?
Keep coming. Okay. Are you ready?
And, Caroline, this is for you.
There's a ballet school right down the street.
Just past your parents' house, actually.
Don't tell me you bought this house just to rub my parents' noses in your success?
Well, that wasn't the only reason.
This is the life I promised you.
it's beautiful, but you know, we don't need all of this to be...
PHINEAS: It only took me 25 years, but...
PHINEAS: Hey, sweetheart, who's that young man over there?
A bit of a scandal, they say.
His last play was a hit in London.
You pay good money to watch people stand around and talk for two hours, and they call me a con man.
Ew, what's that smell? Do you smell that?
Oh, I know what it is. Peanuts.
I can see it right now.
"Youngest prima ballerina in the history of the City Ballet." I'm quitting.
I started too late. I'll never catch up.
Caroline, you were the best dancer on that stage.
What? You think I can't spot talent?
Ballet takes years of hard work.
She just feels out of place with the other girls.
Well, I should certainly hope so.
I've never seen so many little prima Donnas in my life.
Yeah, but those prima Donnas are the most important thing in the world to her right now.
She'll learn to ignore them just like I did.
New York society will never accept us.
If they did, they'd have to stop judging and actually do something with their lives.
So it's different than everything else then?
I just want her to be proud of who she is, of her family.
We don't have to be the Carlyles.
Mr. Carlyle. You produced this play?
Refunds are available at the front box office.
But I have seen the crowds.
People leave your shows a great deal happier than when they came in, which is much more than I can say for my play.
And yet, you have no trouble selling tickets.
Can I buy you a drink?
I wanna go after the carriage trade.
Present legitimate acts, expand our appeal, go after the snobs.
If you only knew how suffocating they are.
You clearly have a flair for show business.
Teach me how to appeal to the highbrows.
Mr. Barnum, I can't just run off and join the circus.
Why not? Sounds thrilling, doesn't it?
Let's just say that I find it much more comfortable admiring your show from afar.
Do you understand that just associating with you could cost me my inheritance?
Oh, it could cost you more than that.
But, on the other hand, well, you just might find yourself a free man.

W.D., Anne, I wanna introduce my newest hire, Mr. Phillip Carlyle.
It's a pleasure to meet you.
And what is your act, Mr. Carlyle?
A bit of a nasty element.
Nothing draws a crowd quite like a crowd.
We don't want you in our city!
PHINEAS: "Shame of the city." "The protests cement Mr. Barnum's reputation as a purveyor of the offensive and indecent" "Offensive and indecent." Mr. Bennett, I am blushing.
HELEN: No, I'm blushing.  WOMAN: What do you care what Bennett thinks?
Yeah, and all the snobs in New York read him.
He does their thinking for them.
Whatever happened to thriving off controversy?
Do you have any thoughts on this?
As a matter of fact, I do.
"The Master of the Household "has it in command of the Queen "to invite Mr. Phineas T. Barnum "and his theatrical troupe to a reception at Buckingham Palace." The Queen Victoria? Is this real?
I had to pull a few strings.
If you want society to accept you, you may as well start...
I guess I'll just have to tell the Queen that either all of us go...
Can't get much better than that.
PHILLIP: Why aren't we in tails?
LETTIE: Don't see you in a costume.
Your Majesty, Mr. Phineas T. Barnum and his...
WOMAN: Is that... is that real?
The honor is mine, Mr. Barnum.
And I've heard all about your little colonel from my friends in America.
You're even smaller than I imagined.
Well, you're not exactly reaching the top shelf yourself, sweetheart.
She's the most famous performer in all of Europe.
She's sold out La Scala a dozen times.
Not to mention the French Opera.
Following you,  so you can introduce me to Miss Lind.
Yeah, exactly. You don't just march up to someone like this.
And this extraordinary gentleman next to me...
Of course, you are the American.
I believe I might have heard of you.
Oh, well, if you've heard of me all the way over here, I must be doing something right.
Well, in the world of publicity, there's hardly a difference.
I believe those are the words of a scoundrel, Mr. Barnum.
A showman, Miss Lind, just a showman.
The best on my side of the Atlantic.
Well, if you do say so yourself.
I do, but I don't have to.
No, he is one of the best.
Oh, that's very kind of you.
let me get to the point.
I'd like to bring you to New York.
And if you agree, I'll make you the most famous singer not in Europe, but in the entire world.
And have you heard me sing?
But like mine, your reputation precedes you, and, well, I trust your reputation more than my own taste, so...
You will sing in the grandest theater with the finest orchestra in the greatest city on Earth.
And at 20 percent of the gate, it'll be a queen's ransom for your efforts.
I give most of my earnings to charity, Mr. Barnum.
"Voice of a Nightingale, Heart of an Angel." That's brilliant. I mean, the press will go crazy for that story.
May I ask you something, Mr. Barnum?
People come to my show for the pleasure of being hoodwinked.
Just once, I'd love to give them something real.
Everyone is here. Look at this.
I will be if this works.
Oh, God. I hope she can sing.
PHINEAS: What's taking her so long?
Torn and Lettie, the others, they've just arrived.
Where should I put 'em? Your box?
That box? No, no, no, that's a bit visible.
The acoustics are actually better in the standing room.
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for your patience.
MAN: He's out of his element.
I recently had the privilege of hearing the most divine voice I've ever heard.
PHINEAS: Now, I know that sounds like Barnum humbug...
but I have 100 bottles of good champagne on ice that says this isn't just another sideshow novelty.

Jenny, this is my wife, Charity, and our girls.

And your father tells me you're a fan of the ballet.
You look like a princess, ma'am.
Enough to bring joy to the most joyless critic, isn't she?
Mmm. And in the hands of a real purveyor of the arts,  she could be something in this country.
Shame, she's fallen in with you.

WOMAN: Mr. Barnum, I'd love to meet Miss Lind.
PHINEAS: And you will meet Miss Lind.
If you just give me a moment...
I'd like you to meet Charity's parents.
How do you do? Very nice to meet you.
Yes, yes, those are your granddaughters.
You afraid I'm gonna embarrass your parents in front of their fancy friends?
I... I really don't think I have that power.
An insignificant man like me who was clearly destined to lead an insignificant life.
All that fortune, and still just the tailor's boy.
I believe I told you that free champagne is a recipe for disaster.
Now would everyone please  raise their glasses?
To Mr. Barnum, who has shown once and for all that a man's station is limited only by his imagination.
It's hard to understand wealth and privilege when you're born into it.
I sometimes don't feel like I belong here.
I was born out of wedlock...
and that brought shame upon my family.
And life always manages to remind me that I don't deserve a place in this world.
And that... leaves a hole that no ovation can ever fill.
Think she likes a man in uniform?
Okay, what are you doing here?
You got a show in an hour, okay?
That's enough time for us to have at least three drinks, right?
It's very crowded in here, okay?
And I can't have you mingling... guys!
Who's gonna pay admission if you're out there for all the world to see?
PHINEAS: Ladies and gentlemen, a toast!
Jenny, America may not know it yet...
but they are going to love you.

Why do you need to tour the country?
Why did Napoleon march on Russia?
Just get the cheapest musicians you can and watch that.
We'll still have to board them.
We'll get married ones, they can share a bunk.
These are the most famous theaters in the country.
They make you buy the seats in advance just to book them.
Yeah. I took out a loan.
And we have to pay Jenny in advance?
It was a large loan. Okay?
You're not gonna see a penny of profit until your 40th show...
You're risking everything you've built here.
How do you think I built it?
We'll have plenty of profits to go around after this.
Your attention has been divided long enough.
Our gate is down, we have more protesters every day.
You just need to get people to come back.
"If you haven't been to the Barnum Museum lately, you haven't been at the Barnum Museum." They come to see you.
Well, then how about you show them a smile? That'd be unusual.
Keep rehearsing. Just make it very clear I expect them to afford you all the deference you deserve and that they should be nice to you anyway.
LETTIE: Ain't that a sight for sore eyes?
Couldn't even say "hello." Or "goodbye." He's going on tour.
Don't you have somewhere to be?
Mr. Barnum said he left a ticket for me.
I... I believe there's only supposed to be one.
No, there's meant to be two.
I wasn't sure you'd come if I asked.
I've always wanted to go to the theater.
MR. CARLYLE: Phillip, is that you?

but parading around with the help?

then I don't want any part of it.
Why do you care what they think?
You've never had somebody look at you the way your parents looked at me.
The way everyone would look at us.
